refnamediv.refpurpose: A few example Python programs using libvips

refentry.para: This page shows a few libvips examples using Python. They will work with small syntax changes in any language with a libvips binding.
The libvips test suite is written in Python and exercises every operation in the API. It’s also a useful source of examples.

refsect3.title: Average a region of interest box on an image
refsect3.programlisting:
#!/usr/bin/python3
import sys import pyvips
left = 10 top = 10 width = 64 height = 64
image = pyvips.Image.new_from_file(sys.argv[1]) roi = image.crop(left, top, width, height) print('average:', roi.avg())

refsect3.title: libvips and numpy
refsect3.para: You can use pyvips.Image.new_from_memory() to make a vips image from an area of memory. The memory array needs to be laid out band-interleaved, as a set of scanlines, with no padding between lines.

refsect3.title: Build huge image mosaic
refsect3.para: This makes a 100,000 x 100,000 black image, then inserts all the images you pass on the command-line into it at random positions. libvips is able to run this program in sequential mode: it’ll open all the input images at the same time, and stream pixels from them as it needs them to generate the output.
To test it, first make a large 1-bit image. This command will take the green channel and write as a 1-bit fax image. wtc.jpg is a test 10,000 x 10,000 jpeg:
Now make 1,000 copies of that image in a subdirectory:
refsect3.programlisting: $ mkdir test $ for i in {1..1000}; do cp x.tif test/$i.tif; done
refsect3.para: And run this Python program on them:
refsect3.programlisting: $ time python try255.py x.tif[squash,compression=ccittfax4,strip,bigtiff] test/* real 1m59.924s user 4m5.388s sys 0m8.936s
refsect3.para: It completes in just under two minutes on this laptop, and needs about 7gb of RAM to run. It would need about the same amount of memory for a full-colour RGB image, I was just keen to keep disc usage down.
If you wanted to handle transparency, or if you wanted mixed CMYK and RGB images, you’d need to do some more work to convert them all into the same colourspace before inserting them.
